discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Kubernetes-Grid/2.2/using-tkg/workload-packages-externaldns.html#:~:text=ExternalDNS%20supports%20creating%20records%20for,Contour%20package%20in%20the%20cluster.

C. Kubernetes services: External DNS can create DNS records for Kubernetes Services of type "LoadBalancer" and "NodePort" to map them to external IP addresses or nodes.

E. Contour HTTPProxy: Contour is an Ingress controller for Kubernetes, and it can work with External DNS to create DNS records for Kubernetes Ingress resources, including those defined using Contour's custom resource called "HTTPProxy." This enables you to associate custom domain names with your services through Ingress resources managed by Contour and External DNS.

questions.question_text: Which two resources can External DNS create records for? (Choose two.)
What is the correct resource hierarchy order in VMware Tanzu Mission Control?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Organization -> Cluster Groups -> Clusters -> Namespaces -> Workloads

The full hierarchy with namespaces included looks like this:
Organization -> Cluster Groups -> Clusters -> Namespaces

Selected Answer: D
In the TMC Org page, cluster group is created first and then clusters are attached to the clusters group created.

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tanzumc-concepts/GUID-E2B5BE05-596E-4999-9B21-1CDB875A1BBF.html#GUID-E2B5BE05-596E-4999-9B21-1CDB875A1BBF
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tanzumc-concepts/GUID-EB9C6D83-1132-444F-8218-F264E43F25BD.html
D. Organization -> Cluster Groups -> Clusters

questions.question_text: Which set of tools can be used to attach a Kubernetes cluster to VMware Tanzu Mission Control?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
kubectl is the command-line tool for interacting with the Kubernetes API, allowing you to manage and control Kubernetes clusters by deploying applications, managing resources, and viewing logs.

B. 
As per chatGPt: kubectl is used briefly to apply the manifest, but Tanzu CLI and Tanzu Mission Control Web UI are the main tools for the attachment process itself.

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tanzumc-using/GUID-6DF2CE3E-DD07-499B-BC5E-6B3B2E02A070.html

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tmc-getting-started/attach-existing-cluster.html
Answer should be D.
Ref: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tanzumc-using/GUID-6DF2CE3E-DD07-499B-BC5E-6B3B2E02A070.html
D. kubectl and VMware Tanzu Mission Control Web UI

choices.A: Tanzu CLI and VMware vSphere Web UI
choices.B: Tanzu CLI and VMware Tanzu Mission Control Web UI
choices.C: kubectl and VMware vSphere Web UI
choices.D: kubectl and VMware Tanzu Mission Control Web UI

questions.question_text:
A Tanzu Mission Control administrator would like to enforce the following container controls:
Only allows container images that match the specified names or tags.
Ensure that the container image is not tampered with.
Which type of policy can be used?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Allowing container images that match specific names or tags: Directly controlled by an Image Security Policy.
Ensuring the image is not tampered with: Image Security Policies handle this by verifying image signatures and using tools like Notary or cosign.
Option D

Selected Answer: D
D. image registry policy,
The allowed-name-tag recipe allows you to create rules using an image name or tag name or both.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tanzumc-using/GUID-BEC4B7B9-B318-4DE8-A03A-FA8C06C155FE.html?hWord=N4IghgNiBcIC5gOYgL5A

D. Image Registry
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tanzumc-using/GUID-CC4B763A-6515-471A-BCA1-307C47FFC36B.html

D. Image Security
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Mission-Control/services/tanzumc-using/GUID-CC4B763A-6515-471A-BCA1-307C47FFC36B.html
+1. Correct Answer is "Image Registry"
D. Image Registry

questions.question_text:
An administrator was requested to create a pod with two interfaces to separate the application and management traffic for security reasons.
Which two packages have to be installed in VMware Tanzu Kubernetes Grid cluster to satisfy the requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
AC, multus-cni Requires cert-manager

Selected Answer: AE
As documentation, the prerequisites/installation steps for multus does not mention cert-manager as prerequisites. While for other packages like, harbor/promethues/grafana/fluent-bit, cert-manager is prereq and is mentioned under the installation steps of these individual components. However, for External DNS and Multus, cert manager is not shown as prereq or under installation step as required. As per question, ask is to isolate application and mgmt traffic and usually application is exposed using contour as ingress. Hence possibly, answer should be multus and contour

Selected Answer: AC
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Packages/2023.11.21/tanzu-packages/packages-cert-mgr-super.html
The Cert Manager package provides certificate management for the TKG cluster. Cert Manager is a prerequisite for all other Tanzu packages and therefore must be the first package you install.

Selected Answer: AC
Gnocchi is right. It's A and C.

Answer is A and C. Multus-cni requires cert-manager to deploy.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Kubernetes-Grid/2.3/tkg-deploy-mc/workload-packages-index.html

A. multus: Multus is a CNI plugin for Kubernetes that allows you to attach multiple network interfaces to pods.

E. contour: Contour is an Ingress controller for Kubernetes, and while it is not directly related to creating multiple interfaces for pods, it can be used in conjunction with other networking solutions like multus to manage the routing and traffic handling for your applications.
